captions.text:
00:10
COMM: To the amazement of shoppers, Yakira

the cheetah is happy to be centre of attention
as she poses for photographs outside this
South African supermarket.

00:35
COMM: Although Yakira is tame, she is not

a pet. She was raised at the Kwa Cheetah Project
by Desmond and Elizke Gouws, at the Kwa Cheetah

Project where the vulnerable species is bred
and later released into the wild.

00:49
COMM: But because Yakira’s mother sat on

her when she was young, breaking her hip,
she can never fend for herself.

00:57
ELIZKE: She spends too much time with humans,

which is not a bad thing um you know given
the situation with her legs unfortunately

she wont be able to released one day and be
free.

01:11
COMM: Growing up with the family dogs Sailor

and Gina and the rescued meerkat, Zulu, Yakira
is about as tame as a cheetah can be, and

she interacts with guests who visit the game
reserve as well as visiting schools to spread
awareness about cheetah conservation.

01:30
COMM: Today, Yakira needs to go to the vets

for an X ray – and happily sits in the backseat
of the car. Although she is quite curious

at what she can see through the windscreen,
she travels unsecured and doesn’t cause
any disturbance during the journey.

01:53
ELIZKE: Your limo is waiting come.

01:57
COMM: On the way back from the vets, they

stop at the supermarket for some groceries.
As Yakira can’t be left in the car in case

she goes to the toilet, she is taken outside
in a harness. Unsurprisingly, she soon attracts
a crowd.

02:12
COMM: While it is sad that Yakira can never

live a normal life in the wild, she is well
cared for, and on this occasion was able to

bring a smile to some unsuspecting shoppers’
faces.

title: Rescued Cheetah: Cheetah Loves Walking On A Leash

comments.author: Keshav Naidu

comments.text:
this cheetah's name is Yakira and she is still very much alive and safe at 
the same place, Kwa Cheetah Breeding Project. She will never be released as 
she will only survive a few days. She is now living in the 30 hectares 
camp, and staying at night in our gardens with our dogs, her best and only 
friends. She did not break her hip as in the video, unfortunately the wrong 
info was used because this video was not approved directly by us as it was 
supposed to. No cheetah would ever like to walk on a leash, and footage 
from this original video was taken for educational purposes, and not to be 
made fun of! We are responsible conservationist and will never allow any 
form of hunting or trading with our animals, they are meant for more, to be 
released back into the wild, where they belong. If Yakira was born in the 
wild, she wouldve been dead within a few days due to her injury, which is a 
broken front shoulder and elbow.... not a hip! Feel free to see more of her 
on her own new facebook page, https://www.facebook.com/cheetahyakira?ref=hl 
and learn more about our breeding and re-wilding program 
https://www.facebook.com/kwacheetah?ref=hl where you will be educated on 
the plight of the endangered Cheetah. And yes, unfortunately there are real 
bad people out there exploiting animals for financial gain.﻿

comments.author: Son N

comments.text:
+annie46664 Infant, newborn cheetahs are only as big as very young housecat 
kittens. They weigh between five and ten ounces, less than a third of a 
kilo. If her mother sat on her she's lucky she's alive, let alone only 
having a broken hip. Fully grown cheetahs weigh in at 21 to 72 kilos or 46 
to 159 pounds. Even though females are smaller 46 pounds siding on 5 ounces 
is going to cause injury.

It takes months of healing and therapy to fix a humans broken hip so they 
can resume a near normal life. A baby animal that has to be bottle feed and 
hand raised can't go back to a normal life. She may not have the speed a 
cheetah needs to hunt her proper prey properly. 

If you listened carefully and read the description you should see that the 
people she lives with run a CONSERVATION facility, where the aim is to 
release the young animals into the wild and increase the numbers of an 
endangered species living in their real habitat. This is what's being done 
with many species all over the world.

I share your outrage over the very concept of canned and trophy hunts. I 
almost lost a good job questioning one of my supervisors about her 
husband's hunting habits (subsistence, and donations of what they didn't 
need to family and neighborhood poor and coworkers.).

comments.text:
+TitanIsBack I simply asked Barcroft to perform adequate research, as there 
are countless breeders, breeding for canned hunting purposes, who also 
LEGITIMATELY claim to put their hand-raised, thus TAME and totally 
unsuspecting and overly trusting  animals back into the wild ... but only 
when the time is right & they drive their wealthy hunters (mostly 
unskilled) almost on top of the poor animal, pretending that they'd just 
encountered such by pure chance. I certainly don't know about this couple, 
and am naturally willing to give them the benefit of the doubt, but I have 
first hand experience in wild animals being purchased to be put onto 
certain private game reserves / parks or whatever, purely to be hunted 
down, for an incredible HIGH pre-arranged $um, then stuffed and later 
shipped to the wealthy client as another boastful trophy for him to display 
somewhere. :(  As a South African, I'm merely watching the backs of our 
precious wild animals.
Watch & enjoy this LIVE SAFARI footage of a pride of Lions in the Kruger 
Park this afternoon:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fahSlraFkv8   ~@~ xox
